SourceText: Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.
text: Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.

SourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Remember that there are no bad parents. We are all learning here!
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Remember that there are no bad parents. We are all learning here!

SourceText: 5. Take a break!
text: 5. Take a break!

SourceText: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
text: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.

SourceText: We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad parent if your baby continues to cry after you have done all they can to calm them. You are doing your best!
text: We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad parent if your baby continues to cry after you have done all they can to calm them. You are doing your best!

SourceText: If your baby cries for a long time and does not stop, they might be injured or sick. You should seek medical help immediately.
text: If your baby cries for a long time and does not stop, they might be injured or sick. You should seek medical help immediately.

SourceText: 1. Why do babies cry?
text: 1. Why do babies cry?

SourceText: Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!
text: Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!

SourceText: 3.  Check to see why your baby is crying
text: 3.  Check to see why your baby is crying

SourceText: There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!
text: There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!

SourceText: Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!
text: Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about what to do when your baby is crying:
text: Please select another number if you want to learn more about what to do when your baby is crying:

SourceText: Call someone for help - a family member, a friend. Sometimes just talking with someone is enough, but if you feel overwhelmed, ask someone for help. Calling for help is a sign of strength.
text: Call someone for help - a family member, a friend. Sometimes just talking with someone is enough, but if you feel overwhelmed, ask someone for help. Calling for help is a sign of strength.

SourceText: Today's Tip is about how we can support our children when they are feeling sad, scared, angry, and confused.
text: Today's Tip is about how we can support our children when they are feeling sad, scared, angry, and confused.

SourceText: Be open to your children. They get stressed too - sometimes from different things from you. Allow them to express how they feel and accept their feelings. Try to listen to them and think about how it must feel for them.
text: Be open to your children. They get stressed too - sometimes from different things from you. Allow them to express how they feel and accept their feelings. Try to listen to them and think about how it must feel for them.

SourceText: Here are some tips for how we can help our children learn how to cope with their emotions:
text: Here are some tips for how we can help our children learn how to cope with their emotions:

SourceText: 1. Be open to your child
text: 1. Be open to your child

SourceText: 2. Share your own feelings
text: 2. Share your own feelings

SourceText: 3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings
text: 3. Help your child learn how to talk about feelings

SourceText: 4. Talking about difficult emotions
text: 4. Talking about difficult emotions

SourceText: 5. Notice the positive emotions
text: 5. Notice the positive emotions

SourceText: 6. Show your child that you care
text: 6. Show your child that you care

SourceText: To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: To learn more about one of these, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.

SourceText: Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.
text: Your child will look to you for support and reassurance. Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling. Accept how they feel and give them comfort.

SourceText: When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.
text: When you share your own feelings with your children, you help them recognise their own feelings. It can also help your children learn self-discipline and to understand their own feelings.

SourceText: There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
text: There are 6 basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid. Even babies can feel and express these emotions. As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

SourceText: It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.
text: It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.

SourceText: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!
text: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

SourceText: Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind your child that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.
text: Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind your child that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

SourceText: But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.
text: But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.

SourceText: Hello! A lot of parents struggle when their children have temper tantrums and other demanding behaviours. Today's tip is about how to make this more manageable.
text: Hello! A lot of parents struggle when their children have temper tantrums and other demanding behaviours. Today's tip is about how to make this more manageable.

SourceText: Remember that you can also change the type of messages you receive for an older or younger child. Just select "Tech Support".  Chat to you later!
text: Remember that you can also change the type of messages you receive for an older or younger child. Just select "Tech Support".  Chat to you later!

SourceText: Ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining or tantrums. Your child’s behaviour might at first get worse, but with time they will learn that it does not work. Be consistent and patient. And make sure that you are also giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times. You can do it!
text: Ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining or tantrums. Your child’s behaviour might at first get worse, but with time they will learn that it does not work. Be consistent and patient. And make sure that you are also giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times. You can do it!

SourceText: Here's a video to help you manage your child's temper tantrums.
text: Here's a video to help you manage your child's temper tantrums.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you manage your child's temper tantrums.
text: Here's an audio message to help you manage your child's temper tantrums.

SourceText: Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:
text: Here are 6 steps on how we can reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like tantrums using what we call Ignore:

SourceText: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention
text: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention

SourceText: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore
text: 2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore

SourceText: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child
text: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child

SourceText: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour
text: 4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour

SourceText: 5. Be consistent when ignoring
text: 5. Be consistent when ignoring

SourceText: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times.
text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times.

SourceText: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.
text: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to "6". You can also type "N" to move on.

SourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.

SourceText: Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. But if you are patient and give it time, it really works. You can do this!
text: Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. But if you are patient and give it time, it really works. You can do this!

SourceText: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention
text: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention

SourceText: When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!
text: When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!

SourceText: These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!
text: These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!

SourceText: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.
text: 3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.

SourceText: Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.
text: Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.

SourceText: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.
text: When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.

SourceText: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.
text: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.

SourceText: This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.
text: This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.

SourceText: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!
text: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!

SourceText: Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.
text: Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.

SourceText: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times
text: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times

SourceText: Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.
text: Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.

SourceText: Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.
text: Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.

SourceText: Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.
text: Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.

SourceText: At this time, it is more important that you involve your child in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now your child needs love.
text: At this time, it is more important that you involve your child in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now your child needs love.

SourceText: If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!
text: If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!

SourceText: Try to remain consistent. Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.
text: Try to remain consistent. Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.

SourceText: Today's Parenting Tip is all about Praise. How did the above message make you feel? We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.
text: Today's Parenting Tip is all about Praise. How did the above message make you feel? We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.

SourceText: Praise your children when they are behaving well! They may not show it but you’ll see them doing that good behaviour again…
text: Praise your children when they are behaving well! They may not show it but you’ll see them doing that good behaviour again…

SourceText: Hi! I just wanted to thank you for making this commitment to improve the life of your children. It shows you really care!
text: Hi! I just wanted to thank you for making this commitment to improve the life of your children. It shows you really care!

SourceText: Keep it positive! Make sure your children get lots of praise when they are behaving well. This will make them want to behave that way more often.
text: Keep it positive! Make sure your children get lots of praise when they are behaving well. This will make them want to behave that way more often.

SourceText: We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.
text: We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.

SourceText: Here's an audio message on how you can bring more attention to positive behaviour by praising your child!
text: Here's an audio message on how you can bring more attention to positive behaviour by praising your child!

SourceText: Here's a video on how you can bring more attention to positive behaviour by praising your child!
text: Here's a video on how you can bring more attention to positive behaviour by praising your child!

SourceText: Praise works for our children, too. When you bring more attention to positive behaviour, they are likely to do it more often. They also will feel good about themselves!
text: Praise works for our children, too. When you bring more attention to positive behaviour, they are likely to do it more often. They also will feel good about themselves!

SourceText: Here are 3 simple steps to get it right:
text: Here are 3 simple steps to get it right:

SourceText: 1. Be positive
text: 1. Be positive

SourceText: 2. Be specific
text: 2. Be specific

SourceText: 3. Be enthusiastic
text: 3. Be enthusiastic

SourceText: To learn more about one of these steps, type "1" to "3". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
text: To learn more about one of these steps, type "1" to "3". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.

SourceText: Step 1. Be positive
text: Step 1. Be positive

SourceText: Praise your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.
text: Praise your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

SourceText: Step 2. Be specific

SourceText: Help your child/teen learn how to solve problems. As children get older, they become more independent and sometimes push the boundaries that we create to keep them safe.
text: Help your child/teen learn how to solve problems. As children get older, they become more independent and sometimes push the boundaries that we create to keep them safe.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you teach your child problem-solving skills!

SourceText: Challenges are stressful. But problem-solving can really help. There are 6 basic steps for problem solving:
text: Challenges are stressful. But problem-solving can really help. There are 6 basic steps for problem solving:

SourceText: 1. Identify the problem
text: 1. Identify the problem

SourceText: 2. Think of possible solutions
text: 2. Think of possible solutions

SourceText: 3. Figure out what the results of each solution would be
text: 3. Figure out what the results of each solution would be

SourceText: 4. Choose one solution
text: 4. Choose one solution

SourceText: 5. Try it out!
text: 5. Try it out!

SourceText: 6. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution
text: 6. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution

SourceText: We can also teach our children the same steps.
text: We can also teach our children the same steps.

SourceText: When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems.
text: When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems.

SourceText: Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.
text: Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.

SourceText: Try to find solutions together:
text: Try to find solutions together:

SourceText: • Allow your teen to express how they feel and accept their feelings.
text: • Allow your teen to express how they feel and accept their feelings.

text: • Try to listen to your teen and see things from their perspective.

SourceText: • Thank your teen for being open and trusting you
text: • Thank your teen for being open and trusting you

SourceText: Hello! All children misbehave sometimes. It is normal when they are tired, scared, hungry, or learning independence. Today's tips are all about what to do when our children misbehave…
text: Hello! All children misbehave sometimes. It is normal when they are tired, scared, hungry, or learning independence. Today's tips are all about what to do when our children misbehave…

SourceText: Stop it before it starts! When your children get restless, you can distract them with something interesting or fun: "Come, let's play a game together!"
text: Stop it before it starts! When your children get restless, you can distract them with something interesting or fun: "Come, let's play a game together!"

SourceText: Try to redirect. Stop it before it starts! When your children get restless, you can distract them with something interesting or fun: "Come, let's play a game together!"
text: Try to redirect. Stop it before it starts! When your children get restless, you can distract them with something interesting or fun: "Come, let's play a game together!"

text: Here's an audio message that can help you redirect your child's behaviour when they misbehave.

SourceText: Keep it positive. It is normal to want to say something about your child's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want your child to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."
text: Keep it positive. It is normal to want to say something about your child's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want your child to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."

SourceText: If your baby is starting to crawl or walk, you can also redirect them by physically picking them up and focusing their attention on something else interesting. Use a lively and cheerful voice!
text: If your baby is starting to crawl or walk, you can also redirect them by physically picking them up and focusing their attention on something else interesting. Use a lively and cheerful voice!

SourceText: 2. Try to stay calm when giving the consequence.
text: 2. Try to stay calm when giving the consequence.

SourceText: These behaviours can take the form of whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child.
text: These behaviours can take the form of whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child.

SourceText: 3. Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.
text: 3. Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.

SourceText: But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!
text: But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!

SourceText: 1. Allow your teen to express how they feel and accept their feelings.
text: 1. Allow your teen to express how they feel and accept their feelings.

SourceText: 2. Try to listen to your teen and see things from their perspective.
text: 2. Try to listen to your teen and see things from their perspective.

SourceText: 3. Thank your teen for being open and trusting you
text: 3. Thank your teen for being open and trusting you

SourceText: 4. Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.
text: 4. Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.

SourceText: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention – it is like an attention reward for bad behaviour. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way. This happens to all of us!
text: If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention – it is like an attention reward for bad behaviour. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way. This happens to all of us!

SourceText: Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V. For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.
text: Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V. For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.

SourceText: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum
text: For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum

SourceText: Here are some examples of behaviours and possible consequences:
text: Here are some examples of behaviours and possible consequences:

SourceText: Fighting with siblings -> Take 1 minute pause in separate parts of the room
text: Fighting with siblings -> Take 1 minute pause in separate parts of the room

SourceText: Talking rudely to elders -> Write a letter of apology
text: Talking rudely to elders -> Write a letter of apology

SourceText: Using gadget over the limit -> No gadget use the next day
text: Using gadget over the limit -> No gadget use the next day

SourceText: Sound familiar? But there is an answer! We call it Ignore. And here are 4 steps on how to do it!
text: Sound familiar? But there is an answer! We call it Ignore. And here are 4 steps on how to do it!

SourceText: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention to something new when they demand something from you or are trying to get negative attention.
text: 1. Try to redirect your child's attention to something new when they demand something from you or are trying to get negative attention.

SourceText: Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Need to hold my hand for 10 minutes (kids)
text: Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Need to hold my hand for 10 minutes (kids)

SourceText: Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Cannot see friends for a day (teen)
text: Forgetting safe distancing rules -> Cannot see friends for a day (teen)

SourceText: Refusing to put away toys -> Cannot play with them after dinner (or next hour)
text: Refusing to put away toys -> Cannot play with them after dinner (or next hour)

SourceText: 2. If your child persists, ignore your child's behaviour. You could still be aware of what your child is doing while ignoring.
text: 2. If your child persists, ignore your child's behaviour. You could still be aware of what your child is doing while ignoring.

SourceText: In summary, consequences should be...
text: In summary, consequences should be...

SourceText: 3. Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.
text: 3. Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour.

SourceText: 4. When the behaviour ends, immediately redirect your child to a positive behaviour and praise them.
text: 4. When the behaviour ends, immediately redirect your child to a positive behaviour and praise them.

SourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Using consequences can help teach children self-discipline, independence, decision-making, and responsibility. They help children learn that their actions will have an impact on themselves and others. It is an important step to prepare them for their life outside of the family as they get older.
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Using consequences can help teach children self-discipline, independence, decision-making, and responsibility. They help children learn that their actions will have an impact on themselves and others. It is an important step to prepare them for their life outside of the family as they get older.

SourceText: This takes time AND patience. Normally the behaviour will get worse because your child will try to test your resolve. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.
text: This takes time AND patience. Normally the behaviour will get worse because your child will try to test your resolve. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.

SourceText: It sometimes gets worse before it gets better. Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific  behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.
text: It sometimes gets worse before it gets better. Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific  behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve.

SourceText: Try to remain consistent and calm (you can even Take a Pause). Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.
text: Try to remain consistent and calm (you can even Take a Pause). Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.

SourceText: In summary:
text: In summary:

SourceText: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention before ignoring
text: 1. Try to redirect your child’s attention before ignoring

SourceText: 2. Only ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining and tantrums
text: 2. Only ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining and tantrums

SourceText: 3. Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention
text: 3. Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention

SourceText: 6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention and One-on-One Time

SourceText: COVID-19 has interrupted our daily work, home and school routines. This is hard for children, teenagers and for you. Making new routines can help.

SourceText: Create routines! Your children will feel more secure and safe when they know what is expected of them and how each day will go. Make a plan with them with time for play, meals, chores, school, and sleep.
text: Create routines! Your children will feel more secure and safe when they know what is expected of them and how each day will go. Make a plan with them with time for play, meals, chores, school, and sleep.

SourceText: Daily routines, such as time for schoolwork, play, meals, and sleep, can help our children feel safe and secure. They also give our children a sense of security.
text: Daily routines, such as time for schoolwork, play, meals, and sleep, can help our children feel safe and secure. They also give our children a sense of security.

SourceText: Here are 4 simple tips that you can use when establishing routines with your children:
text: Here are 4 simple tips that you can use when establishing routines with your children:

SourceText: 1. Give one instruction at a time
text: 1. Give one instruction at a time

SourceText: 2. Use transition warnings to help move from one activity to the next one
text: 2. Use transition warnings to help move from one activity to the next one

SourceText: 3. Create regular eating and sleeping times
text: 3. Create regular eating and sleeping times

SourceText: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily routines
text: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily routines

SourceText: 1. Help your younger children learn routines by taking them through the activity step by step. Give one instruction at a time. Praise them each time they follow!
text: 1. Help your younger children learn routines by taking them through the activity step by step. Give one instruction at a time. Praise them each time they follow!

SourceText: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily plans. Set goals and rewards together. Let them plan when they do schoolwork and when they can relax!
text: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily plans. Set goals and rewards together. Let them plan when they do schoolwork and when they can relax!

SourceText: 2. Transition warnings can also be very helpful. They give your child some time to prepare for the next activity: "In 5 minutes it will be time to pack up the toys before bedtime…"
text: 2. Transition warnings can also be very helpful. They give your child some time to prepare for the next activity: "In 5 minutes it will be time to pack up the toys before bedtime…"

SourceText: 3. Regular eating and sleeping times are especially important for babies. Not enough sleep can make your child cranky, irritable, and short tempered.
text: 3. Regular eating and sleeping times are especially important for babies. Not enough sleep can make your child cranky, irritable, and short tempered.

SourceText: • Try to make it quiet and the lights in the room dim.
text: • Try to make it quiet and the lights in the room dim.

SourceText: • Spend some time with your child. You can sing a lullaby or tell a calm story.
text: • Spend some time with your child. You can sing a lullaby or tell a calm story.

SourceText: • Give your child a hug and kiss goodnight before leaving the room.

SourceText: 1. Follow your child’s interest
text: 1. Follow your child’s interest

SourceText: Talk about what interests your child. When your child shows interest in a picture (pointing, patting, looking), use this as a chance to talk about what has attracted your child’s interest
text: Talk about what interests your child. When your child shows interest in a picture (pointing, patting, looking), use this as a chance to talk about what has attracted your child’s interest

SourceText: 2. Use a lively voice
text: 2. Use a lively voice

SourceText: Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.
text: Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.

SourceText: Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolbox! Sharing books with your child will help them to learn to speak, think and focus better. It will also help them to get along with others better, by helping them understand about feelings. Chat to you later!
text: Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolbox! Sharing books with your child will help them to learn to speak, think and focus better. It will also help them to get along with others better, by helping them understand about feelings. Chat to you later!

SourceText: Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help your child learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).
text: Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help your child learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).

SourceText: Always respond positively to whatever your child says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red tomato and says “Apple”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's a tomato!”
text: Always respond positively to whatever your child says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red tomato and says “Apple”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's a tomato!”

SourceText: If your child knows a word and can say that word, ask “What’s that?” and give them the opportunity to say the word and point to it.
text: If your child knows a word and can say that word, ask “What’s that?” and give them the opportunity to say the word and point to it.

SourceText: Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.
text: Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.

SourceText: Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.
text: Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.

SourceText: 7. Babies and Books!

SourceText: Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!
text: Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!

SourceText: “The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”

SourceText: Making a budget.

SourceText: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget can help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.
text: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget can help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.

SourceText: Do you want 4 quick steps to help you make a budget and save money?
text: Do you want 4 quick steps to help you make a budget and save money?

SourceText: Step 1: What do we spend on now?
text: Step 1: What do we spend on now?

SourceText: • Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.
text: • Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.

SourceText: • Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
text: • Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.

SourceText: • Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.

SourceText: Your government or community groups may be giving money, vouchers, or food parcels to families in need. Ask about whether places in your community are giving support.
text: Your government or community groups may be giving money, vouchers, or food parcels to families in need. Ask about whether places in your community are giving support.

SourceText: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Millions of families find that learning ways to manage money as a family reduces family arguments and brings everyone together. That's real success!
text: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Millions of families find that learning ways to manage money as a family reduces family arguments and brings everyone together. That's real success!

SourceText: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet especially due to the COVID-19 pandemic. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. How we understand and talk about money with our children is important. Our children can also help us to spend and save in ways that will benefit the family.
text: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet especially due to the COVID-19 pandemic. When money is tight, this can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. How we understand and talk about money with our children is important. Our children can also help us to spend and save in ways that will benefit the family.

SourceText: Making a budget with your children and teens.
text: Making a budget with your children and teens.

SourceText: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget together helps children understand that we all need to make hard decisions in difficult times. It can also help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.
text: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times. Making a budget together helps children understand that we all need to make hard decisions in difficult times. It can also help you have enough at the end of the month so that you need to borrow less.

SourceText: Do you want 4 quick steps to help you make a budget and save money with your children?
text: Do you want 4 quick steps to help you make a budget and save money with your children?

SourceText: • Discuss with your children what things you could try to spend less on as a family.
text: • Discuss with your children what things you could try to spend less on as a family.

SourceText: Have you been able to use consequences for not following instructions or forgetting household rules with your child or teen? How has it been?
text: Have you been able to use consequences for not following instructions or forgetting household rules with your child or teen? How has it been?

SourceText: Wonderful! When you are able to stay calm, give your child a choice to follow an instruction, and follow through with fair a consequence, you teach your child responsibilities for their actions. Keep it up!
text: Wonderful! When you are able to stay calm, give your child a choice to follow an instruction, and follow through with fair a consequence, you teach your child responsibilities for their actions. Keep it up!

SourceText: Sorry you did not manage well. This can be really difficult so be patient with yourself.
text: Sorry you did not manage well. This can be really difficult so be patient with yourself.

SourceText: What was difficult about using consequences?
text: What was difficult about using consequences?

SourceText: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.
text: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.

SourceText: This is hard to remember! When you give your child a choice, you teach your child decision making skills. It does not always work, but when it does, it helps avoid having to give a consequence and a difficult situation later!
text: This is hard to remember! When you give your child a choice, you teach your child decision making skills. It does not always work, but when it does, it helps avoid having to give a consequence and a difficult situation later!

SourceText: Check to make sure your consequence is fair and reasonable. For example, if your child refuses to help put away their toys, try prohibiting playing with them for an evening instead of threatening to throw them away.
text: Check to make sure your consequence is fair and reasonable. For example, if your child refuses to help put away their toys, try prohibiting playing with them for an evening instead of threatening to throw them away.

SourceText: When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. Next time your child or teen makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!
text: When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. Next time your child or teen makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!

SourceText: Sometimes our children will react in a negative way when receiving a consequence. If your child is younger than 9 and throws a tantrum, you should ignore your child's behaviour until it is over.  If your child is older, you might need to walk away until they calm down.
text: Sometimes our children will react in a negative way when receiving a consequence. If your child is younger than 9 and throws a tantrum, you should ignore your child's behaviour until it is over.  If your child is older, you might need to walk away until they calm down.

SourceText: If you find yourself always having to give consequences to your children for behaving badly, you might need to spend more positive time with them. It will help them feel more loved and secure...and you less stressed!
text: If you find yourself always having to give consequences to your children for behaving badly, you might need to spend more positive time with them. It will help them feel more loved and secure...and you less stressed!

SourceText: Have you noticed and shared emotions with your child or teen recently? How did it make you feel?
text: Have you noticed and shared emotions with your child or teen recently? How did it make you feel?

SourceText: Amazing to hear it made you feel good, keep up the great work. Your child is learning so much from you!
text: Amazing to hear it made you feel good, keep up the great work. Your child is learning so much from you!

SourceText: Noticing and sharing emotions can be difficult at first, but you and your child or teen will get used to it. Keep trying and you will see the positive change!
text: Noticing and sharing emotions can be difficult at first, but you and your child or teen will get used to it. Keep trying and you will see the positive change!

SourceText: What was difficult for you about sharing emotions with your child or teen?
text: What was difficult for you about sharing emotions with your child or teen?

SourceText: Sharing emotions – especially the difficult ones – sets an important example for your child or teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.
text: Sharing emotions – especially the difficult ones – sets an important example for your child or teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.

SourceText: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it, and keep giving the good example by noticing and sharing emotions. Over time, your child or teen will learn to do the same – and they will feel even more loved and cared for.
text: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it, and keep giving the good example by noticing and sharing emotions. Over time, your child or teen will learn to do the same – and they will feel even more loved and cared for.

SourceText: Sharing emotions is about explaining how you are feeling so your child or teen is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later: “I am feeling angry/stressed now, can you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.
text: Sharing emotions is about explaining how you are feeling so your child or teen is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later: “I am feeling angry/stressed now, can you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.

SourceText: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time later on when you feel calmer to explain so that everyone can understand.
text: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time later on when you feel calmer to explain so that everyone can understand.

SourceText: Being specific is not rude or insensitive, it really helps others understand you clearly and prevents confusion in the family. Emotions like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is know how to handle it by taking a few deep breaths before responding.
text: Being specific is not rude or insensitive, it really helps others understand you clearly and prevents confusion in the family. Emotions like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is know how to handle it by taking a few deep breaths before responding.

SourceText: Have you been able to ignore your child's tantrums or other negative demanding behaviours? How has it been?
text: Have you been able to ignore your child's tantrums or other negative demanding behaviours? How has it been?

SourceText: Well done! Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. Good for you for giving it a try and being consistent!
text: Well done! Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. Good for you for giving it a try and being consistent!

SourceText: Sorry you did not manage well. Ignoring our children's whining or tantrums is really hard. Please be patient with yourself.
text: Sorry you did not manage well. Ignoring our children's whining or tantrums is really hard. Please be patient with yourself.

SourceText: What was difficult about using ignore?
text: What was difficult about using ignore?

SourceText: I know, it can be really difficult to stay calm when our children are whining or having a tantrum. Try to think of something that you can do to help like taking a pause. You can do this!
text: I know, it can be really difficult to stay calm when our children are whining or having a tantrum. Try to think of something that you can do to help like taking a pause. You can do this!

SourceText: If you are finding that you are ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, then your child is probably not getting enough positive attention at other times. Try to spend more One-on-One Time with your child!
text: If you are finding that you are ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, then your child is probably not getting enough positive attention at other times. Try to spend more One-on-One Time with your child!

SourceText: Sometimes, our children can have very violent tantrums when they do not get their way, especially if they are used to it. Try to move your child to a place where they will not hurt themselves or others. You may need to firmly hold your child while ignoring their behaviour - but only do this if you can remain calm and  make sure you are not hurting them! Eventually, your child will calm down.
text: Sometimes, our children can have very violent tantrums when they do not get their way, especially if they are used to it. Try to move your child to a place where they will not hurt themselves or others. You may need to firmly hold your child while ignoring their behaviour - but only do this if you can remain calm and  make sure you are not hurting them! Eventually, your child will calm down.

SourceText: I know, it is hard to be consistent! If you ignore a behaviour only some of the time, your child will think it might help them get their way. The more consistent you are, the less they will do it.
text: I know, it is hard to be consistent! If you ignore a behaviour only some of the time, your child will think it might help them get their way. The more consistent you are, the less they will do it.

SourceText: How are you doing with giving your child or teen instructions?
text: How are you doing with giving your child or teen instructions?

SourceText: Great to hear it went well, you are a star!
text: Great to hear it went well, you are a star!

SourceText: Sorry to hear it was difficult for you. Well done for trying!
text: Sorry to hear it was difficult for you. Well done for trying!

SourceText: What was your main challenge?
text: What was your main challenge?

SourceText: I know, our children need time to learn to follow instructions. Be patient, try again, and remember to praise them every time they follow an instruction!
text: I know, our children need time to learn to follow instructions. Be patient, try again, and remember to praise them every time they follow an instruction!

SourceText: I know, it takes some time to get used to giving positive instructions – it’s really worth trying again! Think about behaviour you would love to see your teen do more, and think of positive ways to give that instruction!
text: I know, it takes some time to get used to giving positive instructions – it’s really worth trying again! Think about behaviour you would love to see your teen do more, and think of positive ways to give that instruction!

SourceText: I know, it is hard to remember to give one instruction at a time. When we do it, our child is more likely to listen – so we can praise them even more!
text: I know, it is hard to remember to give one instruction at a time. When we do it, our child is more likely to listen – so we can praise them even more!

SourceText: Sometimes we just expect our children to do what we want them. But when we praise them for it, they feel encouraged to listen again next time!
text: Sometimes we just expect our children to do what we want them. But when we praise them for it, they feel encouraged to listen again next time!

SourceText: It is hard to remember to give realistic instructions. Try to make sure that your child or teen can physically do what you want them to do. Be specific!
text: It is hard to remember to give realistic instructions. Try to make sure that your child or teen can physically do what you want them to do. Be specific!

SourceText: Did you praise your child during one-on-one time or any other time during the day?
text: Did you praise your child during one-on-one time or any other time during the day?

SourceText: It can be hard sometime to remember. Next time you spend one-on-one time, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. You can even say “thank you for spending time with me!”.
text: It can be hard sometime to remember. Next time you spend one-on-one time, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. You can even say “thank you for spending time with me!”.

SourceText: Well done, great job for remembering. How did your child or teen respond?
text: Well done, great job for remembering. How did your child or teen respond?

SourceText: Remember, it takes some time for your child or teen to get used to you praising them. The more time you spend with them, the better it will go!
text: Remember, it takes some time for your child or teen to get used to you praising them. The more time you spend with them, the better it will go!

SourceText: Well done for noticing how your child or teen felt, keep it up!
text: Well done for noticing how your child or teen felt, keep it up!

SourceText: No problem, try to notice how they respond next time!
text: No problem, try to notice how they respond next time!

SourceText: It happens, just be patient. Make sure to keep spending time with your child or teen, so they will value your opinion more and more. When your praise is genuine, you will see the benefits soon!
text: It happens, just be patient. Make sure to keep spending time with your child or teen, so they will value your opinion more and more. When your praise is genuine, you will see the benefits soon!

SourceText: We are models of our children's behaviour. If we practice keeping safe distances, handwashing and treating others with compassion, our children and teenagers will do the same.
text: We are models of our children's behaviour. If we practice keeping safe distances, handwashing and treating others with compassion, our children and teenagers will do the same.

SourceText: Children see and children do,
text: Children see and children do,

SourceText: They like to be like me and you,
text: They like to be like me and you,

SourceText: What you do and what you say,
text: What you do and what you say,

SourceText: Will help to shape them everyday!
text: Will help to shape them everyday!

SourceText: Routines will make your children feel safe and secure. Try to have regular mealtimes and bedtimes. Remember to schedule One-on-One time with your children, too!
text: Routines will make your children feel safe and secure. Try to have regular mealtimes and bedtimes. Remember to schedule One-on-One time with your children, too!

SourceText: Did you know that teens actually like having responsibilities? It makes them feel more independent and grown up. Allow your teen to choose a special job that helps out.
text: Did you know that teens actually like having responsibilities? It makes them feel more independent and grown up. Allow your teen to choose a special job that helps out.

SourceText: When you teach your children about safe distancing, you keep your whole family safe. You keep others safe, too!
text: When you teach your children about safe distancing, you keep your whole family safe. You keep others safe, too!

SourceText: As your teen shows more responsibility, you can also give them extra privileges. Try to share responsibilities equally amongst women/men and girls/boys. Praise your teen whenever they do their job!
text: As your teen shows more responsibility, you can also give them extra privileges. Try to share responsibilities equally amongst women/men and girls/boys. Praise your teen whenever they do their job!

SourceText: You can even make hand washing into a game where children earn points whenever they wash their hands with soap before and after meals. The one with the most points can win a simple, free reward like extra One-on-One Time.
text: You can even make hand washing into a game where children earn points whenever they wash their hands with soap before and after meals. The one with the most points can win a simple, free reward like extra One-on-One Time.

SourceText: Did you manage to establish ONE rule or daily routine together with your child or teen?
text: Did you manage to establish ONE rule or daily routine together with your child or teen?

SourceText: Great to hear it this! Remember, the more we involve our children in setting rules, the more our children will be likely to follow them!
text: Great to hear it this! Remember, the more we involve our children in setting rules, the more our children will be likely to follow them!

SourceText: Did you have any challenges when trying to establish a rule or routine together?
text: Did you have any challenges when trying to establish a rule or routine together?

SourceText: Sorry you did not manage to do this yet. Sit down with your child or teen and try again today - involving your children will make them want to follow the rule more often!
text: Sorry you did not manage to do this yet. Sit down with your child or teen and try again today - involving your children will make them want to follow the rule more often!

SourceText: What was difficult for you about establishing a rule or routine with your child or teen?
text: What was difficult for you about establishing a rule or routine with your child or teen?

SourceText: Amazing! Consistent rules and routines help make your child or teen feel secure. They also keep them safe!
text: Amazing! Consistent rules and routines help make your child or teen feel secure. They also keep them safe!

SourceText: It is always important when establishing rules and routines  as a family to consider the age of each child, so you can come up with age-appropriate routines. This is most important for bedtime, time to come home/play, household chores.
text: It is always important when establishing rules and routines  as a family to consider the age of each child, so you can come up with age-appropriate routines. This is most important for bedtime, time to come home/play, household chores.

SourceText: We should always remember that children learn best from us. The more we follow the rules, they more they will follow the rules too. You can adjust the rule to make sure that it is realistic for everyone to follow it, considering their responsibilities (for example school or work activities).
text: We should always remember that children learn best from us. The more we follow the rules, they more they will follow the rules too. You can adjust the rule to make sure that it is realistic for everyone to follow it, considering their responsibilities (for example school or work activities).

SourceText: When we establish rules together with our children or teens, that helps the family to understand each other better. The rules will be more realistic and our children will be more willing and able to follow the rule.
text: When we establish rules together with our children or teens, that helps the family to understand each other better. The rules will be more realistic and our children will be more willing and able to follow the rule.

SourceText: COVID-19 has interrupted our children's education with school closures and remote learning. It is normal to feel overwhelmed about to do this alone, especially when we also have stress about work and money.
text: COVID-19 has interrupted our children's education with school closures and remote learning. It is normal to feel overwhelmed about to do this alone, especially when we also have stress about work and money.

SourceText: Here are 5 steps that you can do to help your children continue learning during this time:

SourceText: 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork

SourceText: 2. Make learning fun and playful

SourceText: 3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher

SourceText: Step 5. Support your child when they go back to school
text: Step 5. Support your child when they go back to school

SourceText: Tell your child that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves differently to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.
text: Tell your child that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves differently to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.

SourceText: Step 3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher!
text: Step 3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher!

SourceText: Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at your child's pace and be patient with yourself.
text: Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at your child's pace and be patient with yourself.

SourceText: Step 2. Make learning fun and playful
text: Step 2. Make learning fun and playful

SourceText: Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep your child interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!
text: Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep your child interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!

SourceText: Step 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork
text: Step 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork

SourceText: Make a daily plan with your child for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.
text: Make a daily plan with your child for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.

SourceText: Step 4. Stay connected with your child's school and teachers
text: Step 4. Stay connected with your child's school and teachers

SourceText: Find out how to stay in touch with your children’s teacher or school to stay informed, ask questions and get more guidance. If you are struggling or know someone who is struggling with school work or the home situation, please discuss this with a teacher that you feel close to. Parent groups or community groups can also be a good way to support each other with your home schooling.
text: Find out how to stay in touch with your children’s teacher or school to stay informed, ask questions and get more guidance. SourceText: When we are able to have peaceful and loving relationships, our children feel more secure and loved. Today's tip is about how we can support positive family relationships at home.
text: When we are able to have peaceful and loving relationships, our children feel more secure and loved. Today's tip is about how we can support positive family relationships at home.

SourceText: Step 4. Share the load
text: Step 4. Share the load

SourceText: Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members
text: Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members

SourceText: Step 5. Take care of yourself
text: Step 5. Take care of yourself

SourceText: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break
text: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break

SourceText: Step 6. Do nice things together as a family
text: Step 6. Do nice things together as a family

SourceText: Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!
text: Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!

SourceText: Step 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids
text: Step 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids

SourceText: How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.
text: How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.

SourceText: Step 2. Use positive language. It works!
text: Step 2. Use positive language. It works!

SourceText: Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”
text: Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”

SourceText: Decide to take a break from arguing when you see arguments building up, and go into another room or outside if you can.
text: Decide to take a break from arguing when you see arguments building up, and go into another room or outside if you can.

SourceText: You can always type "Help" if you need an activity to help you with stress.
text: You can always type "Help" if you need an activity to help you with stress.

SourceText: Praise others to make them feel appreciated and good about themselves. Simple words like, “Thank you for clearing the dinner,” or “Thank you for watching the baby” can make a big difference
text: Praise others to make them feel appreciated and good about themselves. Simple words like, “Thank you for clearing the dinner,” or “Thank you for watching the baby” can make a big difference

SourceText: Bad communication between adults in the household can have a negative impact on our children. The more we practice modeling peaceful, loving relationships for our children, the more secure and loved they will feel.

SourceText: It‘s hard to feel positive when our kids or teenagers are driving us crazy. We often end up saying “Stop doing that!” But children are much more likely to do what we ask if we give them positive instructions and lots of praise for what they do right.
