SourceText: Today's Tip is about how we can help to protect our children.
text: Today's Tip is about how we can help to protect our children.

SourceText: The idea of talking to children about abuse can be scary. We don't know what to say. But there are some simple things that can help them understand when it is not OK to be touched, and that they can tell you if something ever happens.
text: The idea of talking to children about abuse can be scary. We don't know what to say. But there are some simple things that can help them understand when it is not OK to be touched, and that they can tell you if something ever happens.

SourceText: When you are walking or doing something together it can be easier to chat.
text: When you are walking or doing something together it can be easier to chat.

SourceText: Do you want to learn more about how to protect your child from abuse?
text: Do you want to learn more about how to protect your child from abuse?

SourceText: Here's a video on how you can help protect your child.
text: Here's a video on how you can help protect your child.

SourceText: Here's an audio message on how you can help protect your child.
text: Here's an audio message on how you can help protect your child.

SourceText: Here are 3 things that you should make sure your child knows to protect them from abuse:
text: Here are 3 things that you should make sure your child knows to protect them from abuse:

SourceText: 1. Learn about private parts
text: 1. Learn about private parts

SourceText: 2. Your body belongs to you
text: 2. Your body belongs to you

SourceText: 3. Bad secrets should be told
text: 3. Bad secrets should be told

SourceText: Type "1" to 3" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.
text: Type "1" to 3" to learn more about these tips. Type "N" to stop this tip.

SourceText: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to protect your child from abuse:
text: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to protect your child from abuse:

SourceText: The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.
text: The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.

SourceText: If someone tries to touch your children's private parts they must say NO and tell a grown up that they trust.
text: If someone tries to touch your children's private parts they must say NO and tell a grown up that they trust.

SourceText: 3. Bad secrets should be told.
text: 3. Bad secrets should be told.

SourceText: Your children should tell you if there is a secret that makes them feel worried. You will not be angry. Only nice secrets - like a surprise birthday party - should be kept secret.
text: Your children should tell you if there is a secret that makes them feel worried. You will not be angry. Only nice secrets - like a surprise birthday party - should be kept secret.

SourceText: Hello! We love our children and teenagers, but stress from caregiving and money can make us angry. Here is how we can maintain control and keep calm.
text: Hello! We love our children and teenagers, but stress from caregiving and money can make us angry. Here is how we can maintain control and keep calm.

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need an activity to help you relax or reduce stress. Chat to you later!
text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need an activity to help you relax or reduce stress. Chat to you later!

SourceText: Stress from caregiving can make us angry. Here is how we can maintain control and keep calm.
text: Stress from caregiving can make us angry. Here is how we can maintain control and keep calm.

SourceText: Here's a video to help you maintain control and keep calm when you get angry.
text: Here's a video to help you maintain control and keep calm when you get angry.

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you maintain control and keep calm when you get angry.
text: Here's an audio message to help you maintain control and keep calm when you get angry.

SourceText: Think about what makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?
text: Think about what makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?

SourceText: Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.
text: Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.

SourceText: Here are some things that can prevent bad things from happening when you are angry:
text: Here are some things that can prevent bad things from happening when you are angry:

SourceText: 1. Cut back on drinking alcohol or don’t drink, especially when the kids are awake.
text: 1. Cut back on drinking alcohol or don’t drink, especially when the kids are awake.

SourceText: 2. Do you have weapons or things that can be used to hurt others? Lock them up, hide them or take them out of the home.
text: 2. Do you have weapons or things that can be used to hurt others? Lock them up, hide them or take them out of the home.

SourceText: 3. It’s ok to have your children stay somewhere safe or take them to a place where they can get help.
text: 3. It’s ok to have your children stay somewhere safe or take them to a place where they can get help.

SourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Learning how to manage your anger can help you  avoid some difficult situations.
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Learning how to manage your anger can help you  avoid some difficult situations.

SourceText: Hi! Did you know that research shows if you control your anger or do something positive, you increase your child's brain development? Be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!
text: Hi! Did you know that research shows if you control your anger or do something positive, you increase your child's brain development? Be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!

SourceText: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe location, like a crib, and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
text: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe location, like a crib, and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.

SourceText: We hope that was helpful! Remember you can always type "Help" at anytime if you need an activity to help you relax or reduce stress. Chat to you later!
text: We hope that was helpful! Remember you can always type "Help" at anytime if you need an activity to help you relax or reduce stress. Chat to you later!

SourceText: Hi! Managing anger can be really difficult. Take a break when you feel you are getting angry at your children or someone else.
text: Hi! Managing anger can be really difficult. Take a break when you feel you are getting angry at your children or someone else.

SourceText: Go somewhere else for 5 minutes to regain control of your emotions. If you have safe outdoor space, go outside. You can get through this!
text: Go somewhere else for 5 minutes to regain control of your emotions. If you have safe outdoor space, go outside. You can get through this!

SourceText: Did you know that research shows if you control your anger or do something positive, you increase your child's brain development? Be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!
text: Did you know that research shows if you control your anger or do something positive, you increase your child's brain development? Be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!

SourceText: Here's a video to help you manage your anger!
text: Here's a video to help you manage your anger!

SourceText: Here's an audio message to help you manage your anger!
text: Here's an audio message to help you manage your anger!

SourceText: Hi! How are you feeling?
text: Hi! How are you feeling?

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are not having a good day. It is completely normal to be going through a difficult time now. Remember that you are not alone.
text: Sorry to hear that you are not having a good day. It is completely normal to be going through a difficult time now. Remember that you are not alone.

SourceText: So good to hear that you are doing well. What a wonderful feeling!
text: So good to hear that you are doing well. What a wonderful feeling!

SourceText: Sometimes we're up. Sometimes we're down. And sometimes we are neither up nor down...and that's totally okay!
text: Sometimes we're up. Sometimes we're down. And sometimes we are neither up nor down...and that's totally okay!

SourceText: When you take care of yourself, you take care of your children. We all need to connect. Try to talk to friends, family, and other support networks every day. If it has been a while since you reached out to someone, do it now!
text: When you take care of yourself, you take care of your children. We all need to connect. Try to talk to friends, family, and other support networks every day. If it has been a while since you reached out to someone, do it now!

SourceText: Sorry to hear that you are not having a good day. It is completely normal to be going through a difficult time now. Remember that you are not alone. Here is an activity that might also help...
text: Sorry to hear that you are not having a good day. It is completely normal to be going through a difficult time now. Remember that you are not alone. Here is an activity that might also help...

SourceText: Make a list of healthy activities that you like to do. Here are some suggestions:
text: Make a list of healthy activities that you like to do. Here are some suggestions:

SourceText: • Listening to your favourite music
text: • Listening to your favourite music

SourceText: • Going for a walk (if allowed)
text: • Going for a walk (if allowed)

SourceText: • Doing some exercise
text: • Doing some exercise

SourceText: Stand up and stretch your arms up like you are reaching to the sky. Pretend to push away any clouds and let the sun shine down on you. Stretch to both sides. Stretch to the front and to the back.

SourceText: Let your hand hang by your side. As you breathe in, squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears, scrunch your eyes and face, and hold your breath. Release your breath and then relax your shoulders and body.
text: Let your hand hang by your side. As you breathe in, squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears, scrunch your eyes and face, and hold your breath. Release your breath and then relax your shoulders and body.

SourceText: Relax your arms and let your arms swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.
text: Relax your arms and let your arms swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.

SourceText: Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.
text: Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.

SourceText: Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out.

SourceText: Hello! This is a stressful time, especially for parents. When we are stressed or angry, we do not make the best decisions. Taking the time to care for ourselves will help us care for our children.
text: Hello! This is a stressful time, especially for parents. When we are stressed or angry, we do not make the best decisions. Taking the time to care for ourselves will help us care for our children.

SourceText: Today's tip is about how to keep calm and manage stress in our busy lives.
text: Today's tip is about how to keep calm and manage stress in our busy lives.

SourceText: Let's take a pause together! Take a deep breath and ask yourself, "What am I thinking?"
text: Let's take a pause together! Take a deep breath and ask yourself, "What am I thinking?"

SourceText: Notice if your thoughts are positive or negative. Notice if your emotions are pleasant or unpleasant. Whatever you are feeling, it is okay. Notice how your body feels. Notice anything that hurts or is tense.
text: Notice if your thoughts are positive or negative. Notice if your emotions are pleasant or unpleasant. Whatever you are feeling, it is okay. Notice how your body feels. Notice anything that hurts or is tense.

SourceText: Focus on your breath as it goes in and out. Do this for about 10 breaths.
text: Focus on your breath as it goes in and out. Do this for about 10 breaths.

SourceText: Now, expand your awareness to your whole body. Listen to the sounds in the room.
text: Now, expand your awareness to your whole body. Listen to the sounds in the room.

SourceText: Take a moment to reflect on whether you feel any different.
text: Take a moment to reflect on whether you feel any different.

SourceText: Here's a video about how to keep calm and manage stress in our busy lives.
text: Here's a video about how to keep calm and manage stress in our busy lives.

SourceText: Taking a Pause is a simple relaxation activity that you can do whenever you are feeling stressed or worried. It can also be helpful when you find your child is irritating you or has done something wrong.
text: Taking a Pause is a simple relaxation activity that you can do whenever you are feeling stressed or worried. It can also be helpful when you find your child is irritating you or has done something wrong.

SourceText: Well done for Taking a Pause. You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit!
text: Well done for Taking a Pause. You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit!

SourceText: You can do this anytime you are feeling stressed. It gives you a chance to be calmer. Even a few deep breaths or connecting with the ground beneath you can make a difference. You can also Take a Pause with your Children!
text: You can do this anytime you are feeling stressed. It gives you a chance to be calmer. Even a few deep breaths or connecting with the ground beneath you can make a difference. You can also Take a Pause with your Children!

SourceText: Hi! Were you able to spend 5 minutes or more of One-on-One Time with your children today?
text: Hi! Were you able to spend 5 minutes or more of One-on-One Time with your children today?

SourceText: That's great! How did it go?
text: That's great! How did it go?

SourceText: Good for you! One-on-One Time shows your children that they are important to you. It really makes a difference!
text: Good for you! One-on-One Time shows your children that they are important to you. It really makes a difference!

SourceText: Well done! One-on-One with your children gives you a chance to learn more about your their interests and abilities. You are a star!
text: Well done! One-on-One with your children gives you a chance to learn more about your their interests and abilities. You are a star!

SourceText: Wonderful! Spending One-on-One Time with your children may make them more willing to help out more often. You are doing great!
text: Wonderful! Spending One-on-One Time with your children may make them more willing to help out more often. You are doing great!

SourceText: Excellent job! One-on-One Time helps build a strong positive relationship between you and your children. Try to do it every day!
text: Excellent job! One-on-One Time helps build a strong positive relationship between you and your children. Try to do it every day!

SourceText: Thank you for making the effort to show your children that they are loved and valued. You deserve a gold star!
text: Thank you for making the effort to show your children that they are loved and valued. You deserve a gold star!

SourceText: Would you like some new activities to do with your children?
text: Would you like some new activities to do with your children?

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need an activity. Chat to you later!

SourceText: We understand that spending One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult. Here are some of the main reasons parents struggle. Which one is the closest to you?
text: We understand that spending One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult. Here are some of the main reasons parents struggle. Which one is the closest to you?

SourceText: It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else. Can you think of a time each day that you can make 5 minutes or a bit more? You can even make household chores into a game to do together. Even 5 minutes can make a big difference!
text: It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else. Can you think of a time each day that you can make 5 minutes or a bit more? You can even make household chores into a game to do together. Even 5 minutes can make a big difference!

SourceText: It can make you feel bad if your children do not want to spend One-on-One Time with you. Think to yourself: When are they more open to you? Maybe in the morning or right before bedtime.
text: It can make you feel bad if your children do not want to spend One-on-One Time with you. Think to yourself: When are they more open to you? Maybe in the morning or right before bedtime.

SourceText: If your child wants to do things that are too difficult for you to physically do, you can simply watch your child. Try describing what they are doing like a sports announcer and praising what they do!
text: If your child wants to do things that are too difficult for you to physically do, you can simply watch your child. Try describing what they are doing like a sports announcer and praising what they do!

SourceText: Children often want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. Sometimes you might want to give them some other fun options to do instead (Type: "Help" if you want a suggestion).
text: Children often want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. Sometimes you might want to give them some other fun options to do instead (Type: "Help" if you want a suggestion).

SourceText: You can also just sit next to your child while they are doing something they enjoy (like watching a T.V. show) and show them that you are interested in what they like. If you take their lead they will see that you care.
text: You can also just sit next to your child while they are doing something they enjoy (like watching a T.V. show) and show them that you are interested in what they like. If you take their lead they will see that you care.

SourceText: You can also find something educational to do together with your child on the gadget. Or maybe ask your child to show you what is their favourite thing to do on the gadget. Just be patient. Soon they may open up to other activities, too!
text: You can also find something educational to do together with your child on the gadget. Or maybe ask your child to show you what is their favourite thing to do on the gadget. Just be patient. Soon they may open up to other activities, too!

SourceText: Sometimes our children will suggest activities that are violent or unsafe. Explain why they can't, and try suggesting alternative activities that would be more appropriate. Type "Help" if you want a suggestion.
text: Sometimes our children will suggest activities that are violent or unsafe. Explain why they can't, and try suggesting alternative activities that would be more appropriate. Type "Help" if you want a suggestion.

SourceText: If your child is very young, it is normal for them to have a short attention span and want to do many things during One-on-One Time. Just accept your child and follow their lead moving from one activity to the next.
text: If your child is very young, it is normal for them to have a short attention span and want to do many things during One-on-One Time. Just accept your child and follow their lead moving from one activity to the next.

SourceText: The end of One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult for your child. Try giving your child a Transition Warning about a minute before the end of One-on-One Time: "In one minute, One-on-One Time will be over and it will be time to wash our hands before dinner..."
text: The end of One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult for your child. Try giving your child a Transition Warning about a minute before the end of One-on-One Time: "In one minute, One-on-One Time will be over and it will be time to wash our hands before dinner..."

SourceText: It can be difficult to spend One-on-One Time with each one child when you have more than one child. If possible, you can ask another adult or older sibling to look after the other children while you spend One-on-One Time with one child.
text: It can be difficult to spend One-on-One Time with each one child when you have more than one child. If possible, you can ask another adult or older sibling to look after the other children while you spend One-on-One Time with one child.

SourceText: If your child is too young to understand how long a minute is, then you can set a number of time to repeat the activity: "5 more tries and then it will be time for wash our hands before dinner…"
text: If your child is too young to understand how long a minute is, then you can set a number of time to repeat the activity: "5 more tries and then it will be time for wash our hands before dinner…"

SourceText: You can also spend One-on-One Time with all of your children at once!
text: You can also spend One-on-One Time with all of your children at once!

SourceText: Type "Help" for activities that you can do as a whole family
text: Type "Help" for activities that you can do as a whole family

SourceText: We are sorry to hear that you have been having some difficulties spending One-on-One Time with your children. Please type "Help" for other advice that might be of use to you. Thank you for trying your best!
text: We are sorry to hear that you have been having some difficulties spending One-on-One Time with your children. Please type "Help" for other advice that might be of use to you. Thank you for trying your best!

SourceText: Only give the transition warning once. When One-on-One Time is over, thank your child for spending time with you. Then enthusiastically redirect your child to the next activity like washing hands before dinner.
text: Only give the transition warning once. When One-on-One Time is over, thank your child for spending time with you. Then enthusiastically redirect your child to the next activity like washing hands before dinner.

SourceText: You can also think of times when it would be easier to spend One-on-One Time each child, like later in the evening with an older child after the others have gone to sleep.
text: You can also think of times when it would be easier to spend One-on-One Time each child, like later in the evening with an older child after the others have gone to sleep.

SourceText: Competitive games can be challenging for children (and adults!) if they have difficulty losing. You may want to suggest other activities that you can play together instead of against each other (Type "Help" if you want a suggestion").
text: Competitive games can be challenging for children (and adults!) if they have difficulty losing. You may want to suggest other activities that you can play together instead of against each other (Type "Help" if you want a suggestion").

SourceText: Today's tip is about spending One-on-One Time with Our Children.
text: Today's tip is about spending One-on-One Time with Our Children.

SourceText: Invest in One-on-One Time! The more time you spend with your children, the more likely they will listen to you and behave well at other times. It really works!
text: Invest in One-on-One Time! The more time you spend with your children, the more likely they will listen to you and behave well at other times. It really works!

SourceText: Here's a video about spending one-on-one time with your baby!
text: Here's a video about spending one-on-one time with your baby!

SourceText: Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your baby!
text: Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your baby!

SourceText: The first 1000 days of life are a window of opportunity for your baby. It is when their brain develops faster than any other time in their life. When you spend time with your baby, you build a healthy attachment between you both that will make them feel secure and loved.
text: The first 1000 days of life are a window of opportunity for your baby. It is when their brain develops faster than any other time in their life. When you spend time with your baby, you build a healthy attachment between you both that will make them feel secure and loved.

SourceText: It is normal to struggle to think of what to do with our babies, especially when it seems they just eat, sleep, cry, poop, and repeat. It can be especially challenging when your baby is very young and not able to talk to you.
text: It is normal to struggle to think of what to do with our babies, especially when it seems they just eat, sleep, cry, poop, and repeat. It can be especially challenging when your baby is very young and not able to talk to you.

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your baby. Chat to you later!
text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your baby. Chat to you later!

SourceText: Here are 7 easy tips to make One-on-One Time with your baby a success:
text: Here are 7 easy tips to make One-on-One Time with your baby a success:

SourceText: 1. Do it every day
text: 1. Do it every day

SourceText: 2. Be close to your baby
text: 2. Be close to your baby

SourceText: 3. Let your baby take the lead
text: 3. Let your baby take the lead

SourceText: 4. Observe and listen to your child
text: 4. Observe and listen to your child

SourceText: 5. Play with your baby
text: 5. Play with your baby

SourceText: 6. Talk to your baby
text: 6. Talk to your baby

SourceText: 7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime!
text: 7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime!

SourceText: 1. Do it every day!
text: 1. Do it every day!

SourceText: Try to spend time playing with your baby every day for at least 20 minutes where you are giving them your full attention. Choose a time when you are unlikely to be interrupted. Switch off the television and put away phones.
text: Try to spend time playing with your baby every day for at least 20 minutes where you are giving them your full attention. Choose a time when you are unlikely to be interrupted. Switch off the television and put away phones.

SourceText: 2. Be close to your child.
text: 2. Be close to your child.

SourceText: Skin-to-skin contact is especially important for new-borns and infants. For older toddlers, make sure you are at the same level as they are.
text: Skin-to-skin contact is especially important for new-borns and infants. For older toddlers, make sure you are at the same level as they are.

SourceText: Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Remember that the world is brand new to your child!
text: Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Remember that the world is brand new to your child!

SourceText: 4. Observe your child.
text: 4. Observe your child.

SourceText: See what facial expressions your child is making. Notice what your child is interested in or looking at.
text: See what facial expressions your child is making. Notice what your child is interested in or looking at.

SourceText: Give just enough help to let it be the child’s achievement. It is okay to play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative. If your child gets frustrated, you can reassure your child by gently stroking their back.
text: Give just enough help to let it be the child’s achievement. It is okay to play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative. If your child gets frustrated, you can reassure your child by gently stroking their back.

SourceText: Listen to the sounds or words your child is making. You can even make the same sounds by copying your child!
text: Listen to the sounds or words your child is making. You can even make the same sounds by copying your child!

SourceText: Babies learn through play! Help your child explore the world through the five senses. Let your child use all of their senses when exploring the world. Sometimes when you read to your child, your child will want to put the book in their mouth. That is okay!
text: Babies learn through play! Help your child explore the world through the five senses. Let your child use all of their senses when exploring the world. Sometimes when you read to your child, your child will want to put the book in their mouth. That is okay!

SourceText: Start talking to your baby from the moment they are born (even before when they are in the womb). Did you know your baby can even recognise their name at a very early age? Try saying your baby's name and notice how they respond!
text: Start talking to your baby from the moment they are born (even before when they are in the womb). Did you know your baby can even recognise their name at a very early age? Try saying your baby's name and notice how they respond!

SourceText: Here is a comic about spending one-on-one time with your baby!
text: Here is a comic about spending one-on-one time with your baby!

SourceText: It is okay for your child to want to do many different things. Your child’s attention may wander to many different things during One-on-One Time. Anything that is happening can grab their attention: the sound of a car, the feeling of a breeze from a fan, feelings in the body. Just keep your attention on your child.
text: It is okay for your child to want to do many different things. Your child’s attention may wander to many different things during One-on-One Time. Anything that is happening can grab their attention: the sound of a car, the feeling of a breeze from a fan, feelings in the body. Just keep your attention on your child.

SourceText: Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening. Speak with enthusiasm when describing what your child is doing.
text: Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening. Speak with enthusiasm when describing what your child is doing.

SourceText: Look for ways you can connect with your baby playfully during feeding, bathing, and dressing. You can even make bedtime a fun and nurturing experience for you and your baby in a calm way.
text: Look for ways you can connect with your baby playfully during feeding, bathing, and dressing. You can even make bedtime a fun and nurturing experience for you and your baby in a calm way.

SourceText: Congratulations! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Quality time with your children is the best gift that you can ever give them.
text: Congratulations! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Quality time with your children is the best gift that you can ever give them.

text: Would you like some suggestions for activities to do with your baby?

text: Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your child!

SourceText: One-on-One Time with your children is free and fun. It makes children feel loved and secure, and shows them that they are important. It also increases their confidence and self-esteem!
text: One-on-One Time with your children is free and fun. It makes children feel loved and secure, and shows them that they are important. It also increases their confidence and self-esteem!

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your child. Chat to you later!
text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your child. Chat to you later!

SourceText: Here are 6 tips to make One-on-One Time with your child a success:
text: Here are 6 tips to make One-on-One Time with your child a success:

SourceText: 1. Spend at least five minutes with each child
text: 1. Spend at least five minutes with each child

SourceText: 2. Give your child your full attention
text: 2. Give your child your full attention

SourceText: 3. Let your child choose the activity
text: 3. Let your child choose the activity

SourceText: 4. Follow your child's lead
text: 4. Follow your child's lead

SourceText: 5. Use words to describe what your child is doing
text: 5. Use words to describe what your child is doing

SourceText: 6. Have fun!
text: 6. Have fun!

SourceText: Even 5 minutes a day of quality time makes a big difference. If you have more than one child, try to find time for each individual child. It can be at the same time each day so your children look forward to it.
text: Even 5 minutes a day of quality time makes a big difference. If you have more than one child, try to find time for each individual child. It can be at the same time each day so your children look forward to it.

SourceText: Make sure you will not be interrupted. Finish all your chores, switch off the TV and put your phone on silent. It will show your child, they are important.
text: Make sure you will not be interrupted. Finish all your chores, switch off the TV and put your phone on silent. It will show your child, they are important.

SourceText: Ask your child what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?
text: Ask your child what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?

SourceText: Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative.
text: Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative.

SourceText: Choosing builds their self confidence. If they want to do something that isn’t okay, then this is a chance to talk with them about this.
text: Choosing builds their self confidence. If they want to do something that isn’t okay, then this is a chance to talk with them about this.

SourceText: If your child cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like.
text: If your child cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like.

SourceText: Listening to your child is more important than talking to them at this time. If you do talk you should describe what your child is doing. Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening!
text: Listening to your child is more important than talking to them at this time. If you do talk you should describe what your child is doing. Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening!

SourceText: One-on-One Time with your child can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after playing with your child.
text: One-on-One Time with your child can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after playing with your child.

SourceText: Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your teen!
text: Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your teen!

SourceText: When we have difficult relationships with our teenagers, it can be hard to find pleasure from spending time with them. Instead, we spend a lot of time disciplining them or complaining about how they are behaving.
text: When we have difficult relationships with our teenagers, it can be hard to find pleasure from spending time with them. Instead, we spend a lot of time disciplining them or complaining about how they are behaving.

SourceText: One-on-One Time with your teen helps build a positive and trusting relationship. When you really notice them and listen to what they are saying and what they like, you make them feel valued and appreciated.
text: One-on-One Time with your teen helps build a positive and trusting relationship. When you really notice them and listen to what they are saying and what they like, you make them feel valued and appreciated.

SourceText: That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your teen. Chat to you later!
text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" whenever you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your teen. Chat to you later!

SourceText: Here are 6 tips on how to make One-on-One Time a positive experience for you and your teen:
text: Here are 6 tips on how to make One-on-One Time a positive experience for you and your teen:

SourceText: 2. Let your teen choose the activity
text: 2. Let your teen choose the activity

SourceText: 3. Follow your teen's lead
text: 3. Follow your teen's lead

SourceText: 4. Give your teen your full attention
text: 4. Give your teen your full attention

SourceText: 5. Show your teen you are really listening
text: 5. Show your teen you are really listening

SourceText: Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. Your teen might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy having this dedicated time with you!
text: Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. Your teen might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy having this dedicated time with you!

SourceText: Try to follow your teen's lead during One-on-One Time. Accept their suggestions. Remember this is your teen's activity. Your job is to show an interest and say something nice.
text: Try to follow your teen's lead during One-on-One Time. Accept their suggestions. Remember this is your teen's activity. Your job is to show an interest and say something nice.

SourceText: Set aside a specific time to spend One-on-One Time with your teen each day. Choose a time when you and our teen will not be interrupted and when your teen does not have something else that they want to do, like watching TV or playing with phones.
text: Set aside a specific time to spend One-on-One Time with your teen each day. Choose a time when you and our teen will not be interrupted and when your teen does not have something else that they want to do, like watching TV or playing with phones.

SourceText: Try to do something different than watching TV or playing with a tablet/phone. However, you may need to at first join your teen and watch their favourite TV programme with them. They may feel comfortable doing other activities with time.
text: Try to do something different than watching TV or playing with a tablet/phone. However, you may need to at first join your teen and watch their favourite TV programme with them. They may feel comfortable doing other activities with time.

SourceText: You can even try rephrasing back what your teen says when they speak to you. For example, when your teen says, “This math problem is really hard,” you can say, “Yeah, I see that you are finding it difficult.” It shows you are really listening to them and will make them feel supported.
text: You can even try rephrasing back what your teen says when they speak to you. For example, when your teen says, “This math problem is really hard,” you can say, “Yeah, I see that you are finding it difficult.” It shows you are really listening to them and will make them feel supported.

SourceText: 4. Give your teen all of your attention.
text: 4. Give your teen all of your attention.

SourceText: Switch off the television and put away phones. Make sure you can give all of your attention to your teen.
text: Switch off the television and put away phones. Make sure you can give all of your attention to your teen.

text: Please select another number if you want to learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your teen:

SourceText: Look at your teen. Nodding or “I see” shows your teen you are really paying attention. Accept what they are saying without judging them.
text: Look at your teen. Nodding or “I see” shows your teen you are really paying attention. Accept what they are saying without judging them.

SourceText: We are sorry to hear that this has not been helpful. Not all solutions work for everyone. Here are 6 steps that you can try to find a solution by yourself or with someone else:

SourceText: 1. Take a deep breath.
text: 1. Take a deep breath.

SourceText: 2. Explore the challenge.
text: 2. Explore the challenge.

SourceText: 3. Think of possible solutions.
text: 3. Think of possible solutions.

SourceText: 4. Choose a solution.
text: 4. Choose a solution.

SourceText: 6. Reflect on whether it worked.

SourceText: You should also praise yourself for trying. Parenting is not easy. You are a star just for showing up and caring. You can do it!

SourceText: Do your children ever make you feel like screaming? Give yourself a 10-second pause.
text: Do your children ever make you feel like screaming? Give yourself a 10-second pause.

SourceText: Have you only got 30 seconds? Let's take a quick pause together. It might be helpful.
text: Have you only got 30 seconds? Let's take a quick pause together. It might be helpful.

SourceText: Do you sometimes feel your feelings are too much?
text: Do you sometimes feel your feelings are too much?

SourceText: Talk to someone.
text: Talk to someone.

SourceText: Talk to someone you trust. Talk to a friend. Talk to family. Talk to a plant.
text: Talk to someone you trust. Talk to a friend. Talk to family. Talk to a plant.

SourceText: Get your worries off your chest and then let them go. Even if it’s just for a moment.
text: Get your worries off your chest and then let them go. Even if it’s just for a moment.

SourceText: How do you feel now?
text: How do you feel now?

SourceText: A joy shared is twice the joy. A problem shared is half the problem.
text: A joy shared is twice the joy. A problem shared is half the problem.

SourceText: Choose a song that reflects what you need in this moment. Do you need a gentle song to soothe your tired soul or an upbeat song to help you shake some stress out?
text: Choose a song that reflects what you need in this moment. Do you need a gentle song to soothe your tired soul or an upbeat song to help you shake some stress out?

SourceText: Make a space and move your body to the music. Remember to breathe while you move. Let your breath and the movement go together.
text: Make a space and move your body to the music. Remember to breathe while you move. Let your breath and the movement go together.

SourceText: Even a few minutes of movement can be enough to release stress and lift your mood!
text: Even a few minutes of movement can be enough to release stress and lift your mood!

SourceText: Choose a song that reflects what you need.
text: Choose a song that reflects what you need.

SourceText: Sit down, close your eyes and listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. When you are ready open your eyes again.
text: Sit down, close your eyes and listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. When you are ready open your eyes again.

SourceText: Breath in and out slowly 5 times. Then try responding in a calmer way.
text: Breath in and out slowly 5 times. Then try responding in a calmer way.

SourceText: Five deep breaths.
text: Five deep breaths.

SourceText: Listen to your breath.
text: Listen to your breath.

SourceText: Millions of parents say this helps - A LOT.

SourceText: Try this whenever you are feeling stressed and you need a break to reconnect.
text: Try this whenever you are feeling stressed and you need a break to reconnect.

SourceText: Here is a short relaxation activity for you:
text: Here is a short relaxation activity for you:

SourceText: Do you ever feel something so strongly that you want to run away from it? Here's a short activity that might help!
text: Do you ever feel something so strongly that you want to run away from it? Here's a short activity that might help!

SourceText: This activity uses the magic power of three breaths to stay connected and relaxed.
text: This activity uses the magic power of three breaths to stay connected and relaxed.

SourceText: Here's an activity to relax your body:
text: Here's an activity to relax your body:

SourceText: Here is a quick relaxation activity...
text: Here is a quick relaxation activity...

SourceText: Try again for another ten seconds. Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body? Notice how you feel now.
text: Try again for another ten seconds. Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body? Notice how you feel now.

SourceText: Breathe in to the count of three.
text: Breathe in to the count of three.

SourceText: Instead of moving away from the feeling, let’s move towards it for a moment.
text: Instead of moving away from the feeling, let’s move towards it for a moment.

SourceText: It’s ok. Close your eyes if you feel comfortable. Take a deep breath.
text: It’s ok. Close your eyes if you feel comfortable. Take a deep breath.

SourceText: Become curious. Where are you feeling it in your body? Is it hot or cold? Hard or soft? Tight or loose?
text: Become curious. Where are you feeling it in your body? Is it hot or cold? Hard or soft? Tight or loose?

SourceText: Ask yourself some questions. What is it telling me? What does it need? How can I be kind to myself in this moment?
text: Ask yourself some questions. What is it telling me? What does it need? How can I be kind to myself in this moment?

SourceText: If your mind starts to wander, it’s normal. Just bring it back to the feeling. Keep breathing and feeling.
text: If your mind starts to wander, it’s normal. Just bring it back to the feeling. Keep breathing and feeling.

SourceText: Reassure yourself. It’s ok to feel. Feeling is healing!
text: Reassure yourself. It’s ok to feel. Feeling is healing!

SourceText: Notice your connection with the ground beneath you.
text: Notice your connection with the ground beneath you.

SourceText: What parts of your body touch the ground? What parts of your body don’t?
text: What parts of your body touch the ground? What parts of your body don’t?

SourceText: Notice where it feels warm and where it feels cool.
text: Notice where it feels warm and where it feels cool.

SourceText: Feel the ground underneath you supporting you. Let your body sink into the support of the ground.
text: Feel the ground underneath you supporting you. Let your body sink into the support of the ground.

SourceText: Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
text: Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

SourceText: Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.
text: Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

SourceText: Sit comfortably and close your eyes if you can.
text: Sit comfortably and close your eyes if you can.

SourceText: Imagine a golden ring scanning your body from your feet to your head.
text: Imagine a golden ring scanning your body from your feet to your head.

SourceText: Pay attention as it moves up and down your body. Are there any areas that feel tense? Numb? Painful?
text: Pay attention as it moves up and down your body. Are there any areas that feel tense? Numb? Painful?

SourceText: Focus on those areas for a moment. Breathe in to the area and when you breathe out, try to let go of any tension or pain.
text: Focus on those areas for a moment. Breathe in to the area and when you breathe out, try to let go of any tension or pain.

SourceText: Do this for a few breaths.
text: Do this for a few breaths.

SourceText: Open your eyes. How does your body feel now?
text: Open your eyes. How does your body feel now?

SourceText: Try this next time you find yourself lying in bed unable to sleep!
text: Try this next time you find yourself lying in bed unable to sleep!

SourceText: How do you feel now? Do you feel any different? Deep breathing helps our whole body and mind to calm down.

SourceText: Has anyone told you how incredible you are for being there for your children during a global pandemic? There’s no guidebook for these challenging times but you’re doing it! That makes you amazing.

SourceText: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night). It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!

SourceText: Being a parent is not easy. Try to be patient with yourself and your family, and take some space if you need it. By talking about our challenges calmly, we can solve them together!
text: Being a parent is not easy. Try to be patient with yourself and your family, and take some space if you need it. By talking about our challenges calmly, we can solve them together!

SourceText: It can be difficult to control our anger, especially when they make us really angry. Take a deep breath, and be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!
text: It can be difficult to control our anger, especially when they make us really angry. Take a deep breath, and be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!

SourceText: Sorry that you are having a difficult time with your child. It happens to all of us. Remember, we can choose to behave differently next time.
text: Sorry that you are having a difficult time with your child. It happens to all of us. Remember, we can choose to behave differently next time.

SourceText: Well done! Brain science shows if you control your anger when your child misbehaves, you increase your child's brain development. Be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!
text: Well done! Brain science shows if you control your anger when your child misbehaves, you increase your child's brain development. Be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!

SourceText: Great work! When we respond calmly, our teens are more likely to do the same.
text: Great work! When we respond calmly, our teens are more likely to do the same.

SourceText: Well done for keeping calm in difficult situations – that is definitely not easy to do! You are setting a great example for your child.
text: Well done for keeping calm in difficult situations – that is definitely not easy to do! You are setting a great example for your child.

SourceText: Our children can really drive us crazy sometimes. By responding calmly, they will learn to do the same when something upsets them at home or outside. Your patience will pay off, you will see!
text: Our children can really drive us crazy sometimes. By responding calmly, they will learn to do the same when something upsets them at home or outside. Your patience will pay off, you will see!

SourceText: We all get overwhelmed sometimes. Next time when you feel angry, try taking a deep breath before responding. This helps a lot!
text: We all get overwhelmed sometimes. Next time when you feel angry, try taking a deep breath before responding. This helps a lot!

SourceText: When we get angry, it can be hard to stay calm. Try to recognise your emotions and those of your child, and talk about them later - this helps everyone to understand each other better next time. You can do it!
text: When we get angry, it can be hard to stay calm. Try to recognise your emotions and those of your child, and talk about them later - this helps everyone to understand each other better next time. You can do it!

SourceText: It is great that you can address your child more and more calmly when they upset you. Working through challenges together will help your child so much in life – you are doing amazing!
text: It is great that you can address your child more and more calmly when they upset you. Working through challenges together will help your child so much in life – you are doing amazing!

SourceText: So good that you speak to your child calmly, even when they drive you crazy. You should be proud of yourself! Remember to keep taking deep breaths every time you feel they are testing your patience.
text: So good that you speak to your child calmly, even when they drive you crazy. You should be proud of yourself! Remember to keep taking deep breaths every time you feel they are testing your patience.

SourceText: Wonderful to hear that you are managing to stay calm in difficult situations. You should be proud of yourself – keep up the great work!
text: Wonderful to hear that you are managing to stay calm in difficult situations. You should be proud of yourself – keep up the great work!

SourceText: Amazing! You are setting such a great example for your children on how to respond calmly in difficult situations – keep up the good work!
text: Amazing! You are setting such a great example for your children on how to respond calmly in difficult situations – keep up the good work!

SourceText: It can be so difficult to keep calm when things get out of hand. Try again next time – each day is a new opportunity!
text: It can be so difficult to keep calm when things get out of hand. Try again next time – each day is a new opportunity!

SourceText: Great to see you are managing to respond calmly to your child, that’s a big accomplishment! Celebrate this win, you are a star.
text: Great to see you are managing to respond calmly to your child, that’s a big accomplishment! Celebrate this win, you are a star.

SourceText: It sounds like you are having have a difficult time with your child. This can be really hard so be patient with yourself. Try to take a pause (even one deep breath!) next time and respond differently. You can do it!

SourceText: So good! Every time you choose to be calm and clear, you are showing your child how much you care about them. They will feel heard and loved, and will be more likely to listen to you!
text: So good! Every time you choose to be calm and clear, you are showing your child how much you care about them. They will feel heard and loved, and will be more likely to listen to you!

SourceText: Sometimes everything gets too much! Remember to recognise when you feel that way and take a few deep breaths before responding. Your child will learn from your good example!
text: Sometimes everything gets too much! Remember to recognise when you feel that way and take a few deep breaths before responding. Your child will learn from your good example!

SourceText: Well done for managing your emotions! When things get tough, you can always take a pause and address the problem later on when everyone is calm. You are doing a great job.

SourceText: It is wonderful that you are responding in a calm way when your child does something upsetting. They can learn so much from you!

SourceText: We all struggle to stay calm sometimes. Take a deep breath and remember that mistakes are human. Talking to your child will help more in the end – you are an awesome parent!
text: We all struggle to stay calm sometimes. Take a deep breath and remember that mistakes are human. Talking to your child will help more in the end – you are an awesome parent!

SourceText: Having a positive relationship with our children can be difficult, especially during stressful times. You might want to try spending a little more One-on-One Time with your child. It will show them that they are valued and loved.

SourceText: Bonus question: We all want to keep our children safe. How confident do you feel you are to protect your child from sexual abuse online or in-person? (0=not confident to 7=extremely confident)

SourceText: Being a parent is not easy and comes with lots of stress and responsibilities. Well done for taking the time to learn how to keep your child safe!
text: Being a parent is not easy and comes with lots of stress and responsibilities. Well done for taking the time to learn how to keep your child safe!

SourceText: Being a parent is not easy and comes with lots of stress and responsibilities. It can be difficult to know how to keep our children safe. We are here to support you!
text: Being a parent is not easy and comes with lots of stress and responsibilities. It can be difficult to know how to keep our children safe. We are here to support you!

SourceText: Sometimes it can be hard to know what to do to help keep our children safe. Talk to them and get advice from people you can trust, it really helps!
text: Sometimes it can be hard to know what to do to help keep our children safe. Talk to them and get advice from people you can trust, it really helps!

SourceText: Well done for learning more about how you can keep your child safe. It is not easy, but you are doing a great job – you should be proud of yourself!
text: Well done for learning more about how you can keep your child safe. It is not easy, but you are doing a great job – you should be proud of yourself!

SourceText: So good to hear you are feeling more confident to keep your child safe! Remember, building a positive relationship with your child makes it easier to talk about difficult things, including potential risks. You are doing really well!
text: So good to hear you are feeling more confident to keep your child safe! Remember, building a positive relationship with your child makes it easier to talk about difficult things, including potential risks. You are doing really well!

SourceText: It is hard to know how to keep our children safe, especially if they spend time online or outside the house. By spending time with our children, they will feel free to share with us if they have questions or problems.
text: It is hard to know how to keep our children safe, especially if they spend time online or outside the house. By spending time with our children, they will feel free to share with us if they have questions or problems.

SourceText: Well done for learning more about potential risks and how to protect your child. Knowledge is power – thank you for sharing that power with your child even it makes you feel uncomfortable sometimes!
text: Well done for learning more about potential risks and how to protect your child. Knowledge is power – thank you for sharing that power with your child even it makes you feel uncomfortable sometimes!

SourceText: Talking about difficult things, including the risks of sexual abuse, can be really hard. Well done for making the effort to talk about these difficult topics and questions – it really helps to keep your child safe!
text: Talking about difficult things, including the risks of sexual abuse, can be really hard. Well done for making the effort to talk about these difficult topics and questions – it really helps to keep your child safe!

SourceText: You are not alone! We are all trying to figure out how to best keep our children safe, and nobody has all the answers. We are here to help!
text: You are not alone! We are all trying to figure out how to best keep our children safe, and nobody has all the answers. We are here to help!

SourceText: Great that you are learning more about how to keep your child safe. Nobody has all the answers, but it makes a big difference if you and your child can talk about difficult things together. Keep up the good work!
text: Great that you are learning more about how to keep your child safe. Nobody has all the answers, but it makes a big difference if you and your child can talk about difficult things together. Keep up the good work!

SourceText: Keeping our children safe is not easy, but by working together we can prevent and prepare for so many things! Ask your children what risks they know of, and fill in any gaps together. You make an amazing team!
text: Keeping our children safe is not easy, but by working together we can prevent and prepare for so many things! Ask your children what risks they know of, and fill in any gaps together. You make an amazing team!

SourceText: Sometimes we can feel overwhelmed by the potential dangers around us. Talk to your children and people you can trust. Together we can come up with a plan to keep everyone safe – well done for putting in the work!
